FIGREF1.text: sub-District, NW Province, Pretoria, South AfricaIntroduction: Despite on-going and marked effort being made in South Africa in the reduction of new HIV infections amongst children, HIV/AIDS-related conditions still remain a major cause of under-5 children deaths. One of these efforts, aimed at reducing the number of HIV-infected babies born to HIV-positive mothers, and prevention mother-to-child transmission program was implemented at ANC clinic, Mogwase Health Center. Method and materials: This abstract analyses the causes of HIV infection in babies born to HIV-positive mothers for the January 2010 to December 2015 period. Within this period 1,169 booked HIVpositive pregnant women were counselled on safe infant feeding practices and 1,026 (87.8%) of them were initiated on antiretroviral therapy. Out of 1068 HIV-exposed babies born at the clinic, 1,066 (99.8%) received nevirapine prophylaxis.

FIGREF2.text: In Senegal, the program of Prevention of Transmission mother-child is crossed to the ladder since 2005. The first valuation of the rate of transmission mother-child was made in 2011 with a 4.2 % rate in 2010. The Ministry of Health of the Senegal across Direction to faith against AIDS implemented of numerous interventions like: Option B+, task shifting at peripheral level and elaboration and implementation of regional plans of eTMC. In 2015, another valuation of impact was done.Method: It is about an exhaustive inquiry into the children born in HIV positive mother, between the 1st of January 2011 and the 31st of December 2014 in health facilities in the 14 regions of the Senegal. An active research of loss to follow up conducted in the regions to identified additional statutes of about 600 children represented let be 33 %. This allowed a significant discount among children without serological status ameliorating the validity of the study. This active research was supplemented by the use of database of the laboratory of bacteriology virology and also database of the division to faith against AIDS and the sexually transmissible infections. The results of the inquiry of 2015 were compared with those of the 2011 with the aid of the test of khi2. Results: The period of study was from 2011 till 2014. It concerned 2,730 children born in HIV positive mother. The rate of transmission was calculated according to several hypotheses. The analysis of results at the children shows a rate in 3.1 % in 2014. Conclusion: the evaluation of the program PMTCT showed a discount of the rate of 4.2% transmission in 2010 in 3.1 % in 2014. However, the precocious determination of virology status by children always poses problem. The installation of a circuit of transportation of samples and back from results constitutes a major challenge for the program.

Quiles Saint Joseph Hospital, Marseille, France The recommendations of the Expert Group on the Medical Care of People living with HIV (2013 report) highlight the interest of conducting annual synthesis reports. Circular No. DHOS/M2A/DGS/R12/2007/415 of 19 November 2007 allows carrying out this synthesis as part of hospital day care. The current evolution of HIV infection toward chronicity, the frequency of co-morbidities and co-infections along with population aging, encourage practitioners to provide their patients with personalized and regularly revised care protocols. This assessment should not only focus on the medical validation of the patient's health status (through clinical and laboratory tests, specialized consultations and additional examinations) but also on the achievement of an educational, dietary, psychological and social assessment. The hospital practice time offers the opportunity to include patients in clinical research protocols. We present the 8-year experience (2008-2015) of medical annual synthesis reports performed in the Dermatology department of Saint Joseph Hospital in Marseille, France.

FIGREF7.text: Conclusion: Formation of esophagomediastinal-tracheal/bronchial fistulas is a common complication of tuberculosis of intrathoracic lymph nodes in patients with HIV/M.tuberculosis co-infection. Stenting of esophagus is the effective method of treatment for patients with esophagomediastinal-tracheal/bronchial fistula. This method allows to separate an esophagus and tracheobronchial tree, reduces the risk of development of aspiration pneumonia, and eliminates need of a gastrostomy and esophagostomy. The quality of life of the patients increases, they have possibility of oral administration of TB drugs and HIV therapies.

The aim of this qualitative study was to develop a conceptual model identifying gaps in care coordination along the treatment cascade for HIV-infected PWUD. TABREF3.text: Background: The persistence of integrated HIV DNA within reservoir cells contributes to our inability to achieve viral eradication in infected individuals. At the same time, drug resistance against dolutegravir (DTG)-containing first-line regimens has not yet been observed. We have hypothesized that this is attributable to the fact that the mutations that are selected by DTG at positions R263K and/or H51Y diminish viral replication capacity by as much as 80%. Treatment failure in treatment-experienced, integrase inhibitor-naïve individuals treated with (DTG) is commonly associated with the R263K mutation and the resultant plasma viral loads are usually lower than observed with regimens that do not contain DTG. R263K confers low-level resistance against DTG and also decreases both viral replication capacity and viral integrase activity in short-term infectivity assays. Now, we sought to determine the effect of R263K and/or H51Y on integration over multiple rounds of infection. Methods: We measured HIV integration by Alu-mediated QPCR over 5 weeks of infection of Jurkat cells with WT, R263K and H51Y/R263K viruses. Levels of integration were measured weekly relative to WT virus. Results: The R263K/H51Y substitutions impaired the formation of newly integrated HIV DNA over multiple rounds of infection, beginning with impairments of about 30% in an initial round and declining to <10% when the progeny of the initial infection was used to initiate infection in subsequent rounds. Less impairment was noted if only R263K was present, consistent with the notion that selection of a second mutation at H51Y acts to further impair viral replication rather than acting as a compensatory mutation as is true for other drugs. Conclusions: Our study explains the absence of drug resistance to DTG in first-line therapy and raises the possibility that the presence of the R263KH51Y substitutions might result in fewer cells that contain integrated DNA and a smaller viral reservoir. Studies to confirm this hypothesis using clinical samples are in progress. ≥50% of the viruses tested. Improvement in neutralization breadth and potency was observed with time. CD4bs specific antibodies were found in AIIMS_523 which improved with time. RSC3 depleted flow through of AIIMS_523 plasma exhibited >50%ID50 decrease in neutralization capacity against four pseudoviruses. Semen-originated anti-HIV specific antibodies (IgG and IgA) are able to cross a tight genital epithelium. This observation contrasts with the suggested role of anti-HIV IgA on the inhibition of viral transcytosis but confirms recent data reporting that anti-HIV-IgG may facilitate free-particles transcytosis and therefore enhance the risk of HIV contamination by sexual route.

A great lack of consistency appears in indication, posology and duration.Improving retention in care for HIV+ female sex workers. East Central Uganda of reproductive age who are not sex workers. Despite the scarily situation, there is a disjointed programming to ensure HIV+ FSWs already on treatment are retained in care. John Snow Inc and Bantwana Initiatives Inc implemented Strengthening TB and HIV&AIDS responses in East Uganda (STAR-EC) project to increase access to, coverage of, and utilization of TB and HIV&AIDS services in the East central region. Key priority areas of the project were key population (FSWs) programming with focus to integrate innovative interventions to improve their retention in care and treatment. Materials and methods: STAR-EC/Bantwana initiatives supported HIV+ FSWs from 10 hotspots to form psychosocial support groups of 10-25 membership. Ten (10) groups were formed with a total of 170 FSWs. Groups selected their leaders/contact persons who were tasked to liaise with health workers (H/Ws) to ensure HIV services were provided. Two (2) members of each group were trained as peers/buddies to provide peer to peer support, condom distribution, maintaining a register of new recruits and those who move from one hot spot to another. Peers mobilized fellows for health services, monthly adherence meetings and liaised with H/Ws in cases of stock outs of condoms. They conducted follow up of FSWs who missed clinic appointments and tracked self transfers from one hotspot to another. Additionally, orientations of H/Ws on FSWs' friendly services were conducted. Health facilities identified specific days/or time of the day convenient for FSWs at each facility to access friendly services. Focal point persons at health facilities were identified to work hand in hand with the peers identified from the community. Results: For the time period July to December 2015, the program cumulatively tested 208 HIV+ FSWs, of whom 202 (97%) were linked on ART. Monthly follow ups were done and by end December 2015, 139 (69%) FSW had attended all the six months, 56 (28%) skipped a month of treatment, 5 transferred out, 1 died and only 1 was a lost to follow up patient. Meaningful involvement of FSWs as peers/buddies in health services delivery improves retention of HIV+ FSWs. Direct linkage of community service provider to H/Ws improves collaboration and better retention results for HIV positive clients. On the other hand, high illiteracy levels, stigma and the mobility nature of FSWs' work, make programming a bit more demanding. Conclusion: The model of involving HIV+ female sex workers as peers in the management of their health and health of their fellows can be adopted by health programs targeting key populations with minimal additional resources. TABREF11.text: Matilda Chelimo Saina, Xiuqiong Bi, Raphael Lihana, Raphael Lwembe, Azumi Ishizaki, Annie Panikulam, Rachel Musoke, Mary Owens, Elijah Maritim Songok, Hiroshi Ichimura Kanazawa University Graduate School of Advanced Preventive Medical Sciences, Kanazawa, Japan Introduction: Disease progression varies among HIV-1-infected individuals. The present study aimed to explore possible viral and host factors affecting disease progression in HIV-1-infected children. Methods: Since 2000, 102 HIV-1 vertically infected children have been followed-up in Kenya.Here we studied 29 children (15 male/14 female) who started antiretroviral treatment at <5 years of age (rapid progressors; RP), and 32 (17 male/15 female) who started at >10 years of age (slow progressors; SP). Sequence variations in the HIV-1 gag and nef genes and the MHC-I-related epitopes were compared between the two groups. Results: Based on nef sequences, HIV-1 subtypes A1/D were detected in 62.5%/12.5% of RP and 66.7%/20% of SP, with no significant difference in subtype distribution between groups (P=0.8).

TABREF12.text: National Center of Infectious and Parasitic Diseases, Sofia, Bulgaria, 2 Specialized Hospital for Active Treatment of Infectious and Parasitic Diseases 'Professor Ivan Kirov', Sofia, Bulgaria Introduction: HCV co-infection significantly changes the prognosis of HIV+ patients though the underlying mechanisms remain unveiled. Both viruses elicit inefficient T cell response in the presence of CD4+FoxP3+ CD25hiT regulatory cells (Treg) with perturbed homeostatic function. Treg accelerate liver fibrosis, and CD39+Treg were associated with unfavorable prognosis in HBV and HIV infection. We evaluated the impact of HCV co-infection on the differentiation of Treg in HIV+ patients with virologic response to cART. Patients and methods: Blood samples from HIV+ (n=22,A) and HCV+HIV+ (n=22,B) patients were studied before and 6 months after the start of cART. CD45RA/CCR7/FoxP3/CD39-defined Treg and conventional T (Tcon) subsets, and CD38 molecules (CD38ABC) onFigure P39.1. Neutrophil CD64 surface expression in smokers and nonsmokers CD38 ABC 3819 vs 5249); P>0.05 for all. After 6 mo of cART,CD4 activation persisted only in gr.B (4070, P>0.05). It was combined with differentiation of con CD4 T (RA+R7/RA-R7-ratio 8.9 vs 2.3 at baseline; P<0.05), and domination of effector (RA-Foxp3hi) over resting (RA+FoxP3lo) Treg, (48% vs 15% P<0.01). Gr.A Treg were mainly of non-suppressive (RA-FoxP3lo/neg) phenotype (47% vs 29% eTreg, 24% nTreg, P<0.05). Gr.B was also distinguished by important share of CD39+Treg (42% vs 15% for A; P<0.05), and increase of exhausted CD39+ Tcon (9.2 vs 3.9 for A, P<0.05). Conclusions: In HIV/HCV co-infection, successful cART restores anti-HCV T-cell response together with induction and differentiation of potent Treg. Thus, the additional immune activation mediated by HCV may enhance the exhaustion of viral-specific T cells while increasing the risk of liver damage. Our results underline the importance of simultaneous HIV-and HCV-specific treatment for the co-infected.Influence of microbial translocation and inflammation on CD8 T-cell elevation in primary HIV-1 infectionIntroduction: CD4 T-cell depletion and chronic immune activation are the hallmark of HIV infection. Recently CD8 T cell elevation has been independently linked with non-AIDS events in chronically infected patients treated with antiretroviral therapy (ART). We have previously shown the contribution of early initiation of ART in reduction in CD8 T cell counts. Here, we assessed the association of microbial translocation and inflammatory cytokines with CD8 T cell elevation in the primary HIV-infected patients.

TABREF24.text: Other sexually transmitted diseasesSystematic genital and extra genital screening of Chlamydia trachomatis (CT) on 1545 asymptomatic MSM patients in the STD centers of Bouches-du-Rhône, France CIDAG-CIDDIST des Bouches-du-Rhône, Marseille, France, Laboratory of Bouches-du-Rhône, Marseille, France Aim: The chief aim of this retrospective study was to estimate the prevalence of pharyngeal, rectal and urine Chlamydia trachomatis (CT) infection among asymptomatic men who have sex with men (MSM) consulting in the STD centers of Bouches-du-Rhône through screening report, to estimate the frequency of L strains in rectal localizations and the associated STI frequency. Materials and methods: This retrospective study took place from 2014 to 2015. A systematic pharyngeal, rectal and urine CT infection with a nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) was proposed once a year to every asymptomatic MSM received. Only the ones who have been tested on the three localizations were selected, that meant 1545 persons. The bacterial strain rectal identification concerning CT infection was done in the CNR of Bordeaux. Besides, every participant underwent both blood test for HIV and screening for STIs and syphilis. Results: Within the 1545 patients selected, 180 were CT infected on at least a localization, that is to say 11,65 %. Prevalence of CT was 9,19 % in rectal, 1,87 % in pharyngeal and 2,39 % in urines. Within the 142 patients presenting a rectal localization CT, a typage found 11 L strains. On the 180 CT positives patients, 42 of them presented at least an associated STI, that's to say 22,77 %. Most often, it was Neisseria gonorrhoeae (NG) infection (12,77 %), syphilis (8,33 %) or HIV positivity (4,44 %). Discussion: The isolated urinary screening, much more rarely positive, appeared insufficient. The rectal localization portage is the most frequent. The typage found an asymptomatic L strain on 11 patients which arises the issue of the lack of clinical signs for this infection that is subject to a strong epidemic rebound. The frequency of an associated STI confirmed the importance of a complete screening. Conclusion: These results could encourage to evaluate a systematic CT and NG screening towards the asymptomatics MSM, and to adapt the French regulation.Development of community-led education interventions for human papillomavirus vaccination as a model for future HIV vaccination campaigns cancer (CC) as well as willingness to be vaccinated for HPV in Bamako, Mali. By developing and testing a model for community-led education, GAIA hypothesizes that both the HPV and future HIV vaccine will have higher completion rates and coverage. Materials and methods: Beginning in April 2015, GAIA launched a 6-month campaign using a West African-style printed cloth to illustrate the connection between HPV and CC during education sessions in 4 neighborhoods and 5 clinics. Radio programs were broadcast throughout the city. A questionnaire was proposed to 317 women seeking CC screening at any of the 5 clinics to determine effectiveness of each communication method on knowledge about HPV and CC, as well as willingness to include adolescents in an HPV vaccination program. Results: Only 13% of the 317 women who responded to the questionnaire knew what HPV was, but 70% had heard of CC. 86% wanted the vaccine to be available in Mali, and 84% wanted their child vaccinated, although 45% said they would call their husbands to gain consent. 42%

Godoy 1 , Antonio G.P. Ferreira 2 LATED/VDTEC, Bio-Manguinhos, Fiocruz, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, GPRED/VDTEC, Bio-Manguinhos, Fiocruz, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil Introduction: Zika and Chikungunya virus cause a variety of clinical syndromes, with similar symptoms. As the doctor is increasingly faced with these diseases, the differential diagnosis is becoming of greater importance. Laboratory diagnosis play an important role in ongoingFigure P81.1. Reasons for women coming for cervical cancer screeningeffects to build upon our understanding of the epidemiology and overall the medical importance of arboviruses. Materials and methods: A multiplex one-step real-time PCR discriminatory for Zika and Chikungunya, with an internal control (IC), was standardized with virus culture. To assess the performance of our assay, it was challenged with clinical samples. From Oct/2015 to Jan/2016, plasma were collected from clinical suspected patients. The RNA was extracted with MDx equipment (QIAGEN), the one-step real-time PCR set up was performed automatically with Janus instrument (PerkinElmer) and the amplification was carried on the sequence detection system QuantStudio (Life Technologies). Results: The assay was adjusted for satisfactory performance, reproducibility, specificity and high sensibility. The IC successfully control all steps and reaction. The threshold line was fixed on 0.3. Eight replicates of ten-fold serial dilution (10-10 6 ) of Zika and Chikungunya culture virus were analyzed and showed 100% of detection. A total of 43 samples from patients suspected of Zika and 228 of Chikungunya were analyzed. Our assay detected 11 patients positive to Zika and 63 to Chikungunya. Laboratory diagnosis of Zika is challenging, viral RNA can be detected in serum only during the first days of the illness. Conclusions: Molecular techniques offer high sensitivity and specificity, and rapid availability of information. The approach of screening by real-time PCR is well suited for use in a clinical laboratory and can be easily adapted for high throughput screening. The rapid implementation of this Zika/Chikungunya multiplex NAT assay in Brazil will help identify endemic regions and the management of patients.SARS coronavirus has antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) effect through the autologous antibodies against envelope spikes on Fcγ receptor expressing cells Chun-Sheng Yeh 1,2 , Jyh-Yuan Yang 4 , Wu-Tse Liu 5 , Jason C. TABREF26.text: Sheng-Fan Wang, Wen-Hung Wang, Ko Chang, Yen-Hsu Chen, Sung-Pin Tseng, Chia-Hung Yen, Deng-Chyang Wu, Yi-Ming Arthur Chen Kaohsiung Medical University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan Introduction: Dengue epidemic has been circulating in southern Taiwan, especially in Kaohsiung city. A severe dengue fever (DF) outbreak reported in Taiwan in 2014. Notably, an accident underground pipeline explosion was occurred in the midnight of 1st August and subsequently accompanied with continuous rain. We hypothesized that underground explosion is an important factor to trigger this outbreak. Materials and methods: We collaborated with Kaohsiung Medical University Hospital system to collect 4,400 serum samples from DF patients. The virus isolation was conducted using C6/36 insect cells. RT-PCR and phylogenetic analyses using NS1 and Env gene for serotyping and genotyping respectively. The information of the DF and dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) was collected from Taiwan CDC. The data of precipitation, temperature changes and consecutive raining days in Kaohsiung were offered by Taiwan Central Weather Bureau. Results: The data indicate that there were 15,732 reported cases of DF in 2014, including 15,492 indigenous cases and 240 imported cases. The mass of DF cases were reported in Kaohsiung City (15,043 cases; 95.6%). Results showed that after gas explosion, the percentage of Breatou index (BI) to be above 5-9% (level II) for the measure of mosquito density increasing from 36% to 48% and the DF cases also increased dramatically in 1-2 months after the gas explosion. Phylogenetic tree analysis showed that all the outbreak-associated dengue viruses were belonged to serotype 1 and subgenotype E4. Climate changes have a significant impact on the transmission and incidence of DF. We found rainfall and higher temperature significantly correlate with 2014 dengue outbreak (Spearman correlation analysis; P<0.0001; r=0.87 and 0.78, respectively). Results also indicate that earlier trends of imported DF occurrences significantly caused the later indigenous epidemics or outbreaks during 2005-2014 (Spearman correlation analysis; P<0.0001). We found that the most dengue epidemics in Taiwan sourced from our neighboring countries. Conclusions: We conclude that three main factors that may have been associated with this DF outbreak in Kaohsiung: an underground pipeline explosion combined with subsequent rainfall and higher temperature. These factors may have enhanced mosquito breeding activity, facilitating DENV transmission.Identification of Dengue and Chikungunya viruses among suspected cases of Yellow fever in the Democratic Republic of Congo that can induce the same symptoms in patients enrolled in the yellow fever surveillance in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Materials and methods: Of 652 patients included in the surveillance of yellow fever in DRC from January 2010 to January 2012, 498 were selected for the study. Real time PCR was performed for the detection of dengue, West Nile, Chikungunya, O'Nyong Nyong, Rift Valley fever, Zika and yellow fever viruses. Results: The average age of patients was 24 years. Sixteen cases of dengue (serotypes 1 and 2) and two cases of Chikungunya were found. Tree cases of dengue were found in early July 2010 from Titule (Province Orientale) during the laboratory-confirmed outbreak of yellow fever, suggesting probably a simultaneous circulation of dengue and yellow fever viruses. Conclusion: These findings call medical staff and health authorities for vigilance. A prospective study is needed to establish the epidemiology of these diseases in the DRC.Investigation into an outbreak of Dengue-like illness in Pernambuco, Brazil revealed a co-circulation of Zika, Chikungunya, and Dengue virus type 1Rodrigo Pessôa, João Veras Patriota, Maria De Lourdes De Souza, Alvina Clara Felix, Nubia Mamede, Sabri S. TABREF28.text: Michela Prestes Gomes, Aldaísa Cassanho Forster, Claudia Souza Passador, Maria Eulália Lessa Do Valle Dallora, Antonio Ruffino Netto University of Sao Paulo, Ribeirão Preto Medical School, Sao Paulo, BrazilIntroduction: Tuberculosis (TB) is a serious public health problem in Brazil and worldwide. Still requires research, mainly operating for its control, considering aspects of economic evaluation. Although treatment is offered free of charge, part of the costs involved in the budget of the patients and their families. Objective: To estimate direct and indirect costs incurred to TB patients and their families during treatment, carried out in four health districts covering those in outpatient care, and a hospital specialized school in Ribeirão Preto in São Paulo, Brazil. Methods: Epidemiological study, descriptive type survey, partial cost estimate. Convenience sampling covering 44 TB patients. Data were collected through interviews with patients.

back_matter.text: Aims: Leptospirosis is an emerging zoonosis with a worldwide distribution, more commonly found in developing countries and tropical regions. The global burden of leptospirosis is estimated to be 873,000 severe annual cases and 49,000 deaths. This neglected disease is expected to become an increasingly important health problem due to predicted global climate changes. A part of cases are currently under detected due to similar clinical presentation than other febrile illnesses. There is a need for an accurate and rapid diagnostic test that could detect precociously for increased antibiotic treatment efficacy. The aim of this study is to develop and validate a new generic commercial PCR kit, based on the protocol from the in-house test of the French reference center (CNR), for human leptospirosis diagnostic and monitoring. Materials and methods: DNA was extracted from 0.25 mL of plasma and eluted in 60 μL RNase-free buffer using QIAamp DNA mini Kit (Qiagen). Then, 5 μl of the leptospirosis DNA were added to the 15 μL of the reaction mix. Clinical validation was done on 35 selected blinded samples comparatively with the CNR method. A panel of leptospirosis DNA standard, positive and negative control as well as an internal extraction control were provided in the kit. Results: This assay was specific and showed linearity over a wide range from 1 to 106 l/μL. The 95% detection limit was 0.5 l/μL. Intra-assay variability ranged from 0.57 to 1.11%, whereas the inter-assay variability ranged from 0.31 to 0.51%. The kit is able to detect and quantify all pathogenic strains provided and showed similar bacteremia quantitation with the CNR reference test (Figure P91.1) . Conclusions: The kit derived from the French reference method is one of the first validated, standardized and easy-to-use real-time PCR kit for human leptospirosis diagnostic compatible with pathogenic strains detection and large distribution worldwide.

Multiple retrovirus transmission in feral old world monkeys (Cercopithecidae) from North India Jayashree S. Nandi 1,2 , Anil K. Introduction: Information on the diversity and evolution of nonhuman primate retroviruses is limited by incomplete geographic sampling, particularly from India. Unlike the African primates, Indian Old World Monkeys are not known to be naturally infected by SIVs. This is based on negative results of sero-surveillance of primate plasma samples performed during early days of the AIDS pandemic, although rhesus macaques experimentally infected by SIVmac (variant of the African SIVsm) are used as primate models for HIV/AIDS. The aim of the investigation (1998) (1999) (2000) (2001) (2002) (2003) (2004) (2005) (2006) (2007) (2008) (2009) (2010) was to explore evidence for lentiviral infection of rhesus macaques (Macaca mulatta) and langurs (Semnopithecus entellus) from the Rajasthan forests, infected by novel Type D Simian Retroviruses (SRV) and Simian Foamy Viruses (SFV). Materials and methods: In the absence of commercial tests for SIV, plasma samples of the feral simian species were screened by HIV-1 WB, that identified antibody reactivity in a proportion of samples.
